column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Chapter 24
#Text=The roarings that had stretched in a long line of sound across the face of the forest began to grow intermittent and weaker .
#Text=The stentorian speeches of the artillery continued in some distant encounter , but the crashes of the musketry had almost ceased .
#Text=The youth and his friend of a sudden looked up , feeling a deadened form of distress at the waning of these noises , which had become a part of life .
#Text=They could see changes going on among the troops .
#Text=There were marchings this way and that way .
#Text=A battery wheeled leisurely .
#Text=On the crest of a small hill was the thick gleam of many departing muskets .
#Text=The youth arose .
#Text=" Well , what now , I wonder ? " he said .
#Text=By his tone he seemed to be preparing to resent some new monstrosity in the way of dins and smashes .
#Text=He shaded his eyes with his grimy hand and gazed over the field .
#Text=His friend also arose and stared .
#Text=" I bet we 're goin ' t ' git along out of this an ' back over th ' river , " said he .
#Text=" Well , I swan ! " said the youth .
#Text=They waited , watching .
#Text=Within a little while the regiment received orders to retrace its way .
#Text=The men got up grunting from the grass , regretting the soft repose .
#Text=They jerked their stiffened legs , and stretched their arms over their heads .
#Text=One man swore as he rubbed his eyes .
#Text=They all groaned " O Lord ! "
#Text=They had as many objections to this change as they would have had to a proposal for a new battle .
#Text=They trampled slowly back over the field across which they had run in a mad scamper .
#Text=The regiment marched until it had joined its fellows .
#Text=The reformed brigade , in column , aimed through a wood at the road .
#Text=Directly they were in a mass of dust-covered troops , and were trudging along in a way parallel to the enemy 's lines as these had been defined by the previous turmoil .
#Text=They passed within view of a stolid white house , and saw in front of it groups of their comrades lying in wait behind a neat breastwork .
#Text=A row of guns were booming at a distant enemy .
#Text=Shells thrown in reply were raising clouds of dust and splinters .
#Text=Horsemen dashed along the line of intrenchments .
#Text=At this point of its march the division curved away from the field and went winding off in the direction of the river .
#Text=When the significance of this movement had impressed itself upon the youth
#Text=he turned his head and looked over his shoulder toward the trampled and debris-strewed ground .
#Text=He breathed a breath of new satisfaction .
#Text=He finally nudged his friend .
#Text=" Well , it 's all over , " he said to him .
#Text=His friend gazed backward .
#Text=" B'Gawd , it is , " he assented .
#Text=They mused .
#Text=For a time the youth was obliged to reflect in a puzzled and uncertain way .
#Text=His mind was undergoing a subtle change .
#Text=It took moments for it to cast off its battleful ways and resume its accustomed course of thought .
#Text=Gradually his brain emerged from the clogged clouds , and at last he was enabled to more closely comprehend himself and circumstance .
#Text=He understood then that the existence of shot and countershot was in the past .
#Text=He had dwelt in a land of strange , squalling upheavals and had come forth .
#Text=He had been where there was red of blood and black of passion , and he was escaped .
#Text=His first thoughts were given to rejoicings at this fact .
#Text=Later he began to study his deeds , his failures , and his achievements .
#Text=Thus , fresh from scenes where many of his usual machines of reflection had been idle , from where he had proceeded sheeplike , he struggled to marshal all his acts .
#Text=At last they marched before him clearly .
#Text=From this present view point he was enabled to look upon them in spectator fashion and criticise them with some correctness , for his new condition had already defeated certain sympathies .
#Text=Regarding his procession of memory he felt gleeful and unregretting , for in it his public deeds were paraded in great and shining prominence .
#Text=Those performances which had been witnessed by his fellows marched now in wide purple and gold , having various deflections .
#Text=They went gayly with music .
#Text=It was pleasure to watch these things .
#Text=He spent delightful minutes viewing the gilded images of memory .
#Text=He saw that he was good .
#Text=He recalled with a thrill of joy the respectful comments of his fellows upon his conduct .
#Text=Nevertheless , the ghost of his flight from the first engagement appeared to him and danced .
#Text=There were small shoutings in his brain about these matters .
#Text=For a moment he blushed , and the light of his soul flickered with shame .
#Text=A specter of reproach came to him .

#Text=There loomed the dogging memory of the tattered soldier -- he who , gored by bullets and faint of blood , had fretted concerning an imagined wound in another ; he who had loaned his last of strength and intellect for the tall soldier ; he who , blind with weariness and pain , had been deserted in the field .
#Text=For an instant a wretched chill of sweat was upon him at the thought that he might be detected in the thing .
#Text=As he stood persistently before his vision , he gave vent to a cry of sharp irritation and agony .
#Text=His friend turned .
#Text=" What 's the matter , Henry ? " he demanded .
#Text=The youth 's reply was an outburst of crimson oaths .
